text: HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppresses immune activation and apoptosis through regulation of nuclear factor kappa B [ see comments ]

The HIV-1 accessory gene product <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can influence viral pathogenesis by affecting viral replication as well as host cell transcription and proliferation .
We have investigated the effects of <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on host cell activation and confirm that it influences cellular proliferation .
However , we have also found that <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> modulates T-cell receptor ( TCR ) - triggered apoptosis in a manner similar to that of glucocorticoids .

In the absence of TCR - mediated activation , <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces apoptosis whereas in its presence , <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interrupts the expected induction of apoptosis .

This regulation of apoptosis is linked to <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppression of NF-kappa B activity via the induction of I kappa B , an inhibitor of NF-kappa B . Further , <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppresses expression of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , IL-12 , <extra_id_0> TNF alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , all of which are NF-kappa B - dependent .

text: The effects of <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> could be reversed by RU486 .

Our finding that <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can regulate NF-kappa B supports the hypothesis that some aspects of viral pathogenesis are the consequence of cell dysregulation by <extra_id_0> Vpr <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
